To do this, generate natural language reasoning steps that lead to your final answer.\n\nThe input text is structured as follows:\n- The premises are enclosed within <Premises> and </Premises>.\n- The conclusion is enclosed within <Conclusion> and </Conclusion>.\n- The question is enclosed within <Question> and </Question>.\n- The answer options are provided within <Options> and </Options>.\n\nYour output should include:\n1. A reasoning section enclosed within <Reasoning> and </Reasoning> that explains your thought process.\n2. The final answer enclosed within <Answer> and </Answer>.\n\n\n\nBelow are three examples that demonstrate the desired reasoning style:\n\n<EXAMPLE 1>\n<Premises>\nPeter Parker is either a superhero or a civilian.\nThe Hulk is a destroyer.\nThe Hulk wakes up when he is angry.\nIf the Hulk wakes up, then he will break a bridge.\nThor is a god.\nThor will break a bridge when he is happy.\nA god is not a destroyer.\nPeter Parker wears a uniform when he is a superhero.\nPeter Parker is not a civilian if a destroyer is breaking a bridge.\nIf Thor is happy, the Hulk is angry.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nIf Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform.\n</Question> \n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\nStep 1: given premises \"If Thor is happy, the Hulk is angry.\" and \"The Hulk wakes up when he is angry.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then hulk wakes up.\"\nStep 2: given premise \"If the Hulk wakes up, then he will break a bridge.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then hulk wakes up.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then hulk will break a bridge.\"\nStep 3: given premise \"The Hulk is a destroyer.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then hulk will break a bridge.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then a destroyer will break a bridge.\"\nStep 4: given premise \"Peter Parker is not a civilian if a destroyer is breaking a bridge.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then a destroyer will break a bridge.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is not a civilian\"\nStep 5: given premise \"Peter Parker is either a superhero or a civilian.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is not a civilian\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is a superhero.\"\nStep 6: given premise \"Peter Parker wears a uniform when he is a superhero.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is a superhero.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform\"\nTherefore, the answer is (A).\n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</Answer>\n</EXAMPLE 1>\n\n<EXAMPLE 2>\n<Premises>\nAll philosophers reason.\nSome sophists reason.\nAll who can reason can distinguish truth from falsehood.\nNobody who can distinguish truth from falsehood is morally perfect.\nThe theistic God is morally perfect.\nThe theistic God is a sophist.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nThe theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? The theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</Question>\n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\nStep 1: From the premise \u201cAll philosophers reason,\u201d we know that if someone is a philosopher, then that individual necessarily has the ability to reason.\nStep 2: From the premise \u201cAll who can reason can distinguish truth from falsehood,\u201d we conclude that if someone reasons, they will also distinguish truth from falsehood.\nStep 3: The premise \u201cNobody who can distinguish truth from falsehood is morally perfect\u201d implies that if one does indeed distinguish truth from falsehood, they cannot be morally perfect.\nStep 4: Since the theistic God is stated to be \u201cmorally perfect,\u201d if the theistic God were a philosopher, He would have to reason (by Step 1), which would lead to distinguishing truth from falsehood (by Step 2), thereby making Him not morally perfect (by Step 3). This contradicts the premise that the theistic God is morally perfect, so He cannot be a philosopher.\nStep 5: Separately, the premise says \u201cThe theistic God is a sophist.\u201d We also know \u201cSome sophists reason,\u201d which does not imply that every sophist necessarily reasons. Hence, there is no guaranteed contradiction in being a sophist while remaining morally perfect\u2014He could be the sort of sophist who does not reason.\nStep 6: Because the theistic God cannot be both morally perfect and a philosopher, the statement \u201cThe theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher\u201d is false.\nTherefore, the answer is (B). \n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</Answer>\n</EXAMPLE 2>\n\n<EXAMPLE 3>\n<Premises>\nWilliam Dickinson was a British politician who sat in the House of Commons William Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh. \nThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom. \nWilliam Dickinson supported the Portland Whigs. \nPeople who supported the Portland Whigs did not get a seat in the Parliament.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? William Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</Question> \n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\nStep 1: The premise states that \u201cWilliam Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh.\u201d We also know that \u201cThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom,\u201d so we can confirm that William Dickinson\u2019s university education took place in the UK.\nStep 2: However, the premise does not explicitly state that Westminster School is located in the UK. Although many readers might know from general knowledge that Westminster School is in London, the text itself does not provide this information.\nStep 3: Since the conclusion claims that \u201cWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university,\u201d we can confirm the university part is in the UK but have insufficient information about the high school (Westminster School).\nStep 4: Because the premise does not definitively place Westminster School in the UK, it is impossible to conclude with certainty that both schools he attended were in the UK. We therefore lack enough textual evidence to deem the conclusion strictly true.\nStep 5: There is also no premise suggesting that Westminster School is outside of the UK, so we cannot declare the conclusion false. The conclusion could be true in reality, but the text does not confirm it.\nStep 6: As a result, the statement \u201cWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university\u201d remains unverified by the given premises and is thus uncertain.\nTherefore, the answer is (C). \n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (C).\n</Answer>\n</EXAMPLE 3>\n\n\n\nThe following is the problem you need to solve.\n\n<Premises>\nAll business organizations are legal entities.\nAll companies are business organizations.\nAll private companies are companies.\nAll legal entities are created under law. \nAll legal entities have legal obligations.\nIf the Harvard Weekly Book Club is created under law, then it is not a private company. \n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nThe Harvard Weekly Book club has legal obligations.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? The Harvard Weekly Book club has legal obligations.\n</Question>\n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\n"
            }
        ]

        "premises": "All business organizations are legal entities.\nAll companies are business organizations.\nAll private companies are companies.\nAll legal entities are created under law. \nAll legal entities have legal obligations.\nIf the Harvard Weekly Book Club is created under law, then it is not a private company. ",
        "conclusions": "The Harvard Weekly Book club has legal obligations and is a private company.",
        "rationale": "Step 1: From the premises, we know that all companies are business organizations (Premise 2) and all business organizations are legal entities (Premise 1), which means all companies are legal entities.\nStep 2: Since all companies are legal entities (from Step 1), and all legal entities have legal obligations (Premise 5), it follows that all companies have legal obligations.\nStep 3: The premise states that if the Harvard Weekly Book Club is created under law, then it is not a private company (Premise 6). This implies that if the Harvard Weekly Book Club is a private company, it was not created under law.\nStep 4: From Step 2, we know that all companies have legal obligations. If the Harvard Weekly Book Club is a private company, it would be a company and thus would have legal obligations, which contradicts the premise that if it is created under law, it is not a private company (Premise 6).\nStep 5: However, the premise that all legal entities are created under law (Premise 4) and all legal entities have legal obligations (Premise 5) does not directly help us determine if the Harvard Weekly Book Club is a private company or not, as it could be created under law and still be a private company or not. The critical information about the Harvard Weekly Book Club being a private company or not comes from the direct statement in Premise 6.\nStep 6: Given the direct statement in Premise 6 that if the Harvard Weekly Book Club is created under law, then it is not a private company, we cannot conclude that the Harvard Weekly Book Club is a private company because we do not know if it was created under law or not.\nStep 7: However, we can conclude from Premise 4 that if the Harvard Weekly Book Club is a legal entity, it must be created under law. But from Step 6, if it is created under law, it cannot be a private company. However, this does not directly answer the question of whether it is a private company or not.\nStep 8: Given the premises, we know that all private companies are companies (Premise 3), but the key information about the Harvard Weekly Book Club being a private company or not comes from Premise 6, which creates a contradiction with the possibility of it being a private company if it is created under law. We cannot confirm it is a private company based on the given premises, but we also cannot confirm it is not a private company.\nStep 9: The critical point is that the premises do not directly confirm or deny the Harvard Weekly Book Club being a private company. The only information we have about it being a private company is from the conditional statement in Premise 6, which does not directly apply to the statement that it has legal obligations and is a private company.\nStep 10: The premises confirm that if the Harvard Weekly Book Club is a legal entity, it has legal obligations (from Step 2), but we cannot confirm it is a private company because the premise that it cannot be a private company if created under law (Premise 6) does not directly apply to the question of whether it is a private company or not.\nStep 11: The statement that the Harvard Weekly Book club has legal obligations and is a private company cannot be confirmed or denied directly by the premises because the key information about being a private company is conditional and does not directly apply to the Harvard Weekly Book Club based on the information given.\nStep 12: Therefore, the statement remains uncertain because we cannot confirm it based on the given premises.\nTherefore, the answer is (C).\n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (C).\n</Answer>",

",
        "conclusions": "If the Harvard Weekly Book club is a private company, then it either has legal obligations or is created under law.",
        "rationale": "Step 1: We know that all private companies are companies, and all companies are business organizations. So, if the Harvard Weekly Book club is a private company, it is a company, and therefore a business organization.\n\nStep 2: Since all business organizations are legal entities, and the Harvard Weekly Book club is a business organization (as concluded in Step 1), it is a legal entity.\n\nStep 3: From the premise \"All legal entities are created under law,\" we can deduce that if the Harvard Weekly Book club is a legal entity, it is created under law.\n\nStep 4: Now, we have two conditions: the Harvard Weekly Book club is created under law (from Step 3) and it is a private company (given). We are asked about the implication of it being a private company, so we look at the premise \"If the Harvard Weekly Book club is created under law, then it is not a private company.\" This implies that if it is created under law, it cannot be a private company.\n\nStep 5: However, we have already established that it is a legal entity and thus created under law. Therefore, it cannot be a private company according to the premise from Step 4.\n\nStep 6: Now, we need to assess the conclusion \"If the Harvard Weekly Book club is a private company, then it either has legal obligations or is created under law.\" Given that we have determined the Harvard Weekly Book club cannot be a private company (from Step 5), the conclusion becomes moot because the condition (it being a private company) is false.\n\nTherefore, the answer is (B). \n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</Answer>",

    {
        "premises": "Animals are either invertebrates or vertebrates.\nAll animals with backbones reproduce by male-and-female mating. \nAll vertebrate animals have a backbone.\nAll bees do not reproduce by male-and-female mating.\nAll queen bees are bees.\nHarry is a bee.",
        "conclusions": "Harry is a queen bee.",
        "rationale": "Step 1: From the premise \u201cAll animals are either invertebrates or vertebrates,\u201d we know that any animal must be either an invertebrate or a vertebrate.\nStep 2: The premise \u201cAll animals with backbones reproduce by male-and-female mating\u201d implies that if an animal has a backbone, it must reproduce by male-and-female mating.\nStep 3: The premise \u201cAll vertebrate animals have a backbone\u201d tells us that any vertebrate animal has a backbone.\nStep 4: Combining Steps 2 and 3, we can conclude that any vertebrate animal reproduces by male-and-female mating.\nStep 5: From the premise \u201cAll bees do not reproduce by male-and-female mating,\u201d we can conclude that bees are not vertebrates. Since they don't reproduce by male-and-female mating.\nStep 6: Since bees are not vertebrates and all animals are either invertebrates or vertebrates (Step 1), we can conclude that bees are invertebrates.\nStep 7: Given that all bees are invertebrates and that queen bees are bees (from the premise), we can infer that all queen bees are invertebrates.\nStep 8: However, from the premise \"Animals are either invertebrates or vertebrates\" and the fact that all queen bees are invertebrates, we cannot conclude that Harry is a queen bee solely based on the information that he is a bee. Since we do not have any information that directly links being a bee to being a queen bee or being an invertebrate to being a queen bee, we can only say that Harry is a bee and that bees are invertebrates. \nStep 9: But we can also know that since Harry is a bee and all bees do not reproduce by male-and-female mating, we can conclude that Harry is not a vertebrate (from Step 5).\nStep 10: Combining Steps 6 and 9, we can conclude that Harry is an invertebrate.\nStep 11: Since all queen bees are invertebrates (Step 7) and Harry is an invertebrate (Step 10), it does not follow that Harry must be a queen bee.\nStep 12: The premise does not provide a direct link between being an invertebrate and being a queen bee, so we cannot conclude that Harry is a queen bee with certainty.\nTherefore, the answer is (C).\n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (C).\n</Answer>",
        "label": "Uncertain",
        "predict": "Uncertain",
        "user_prompt": [
            {
                "role": "user",
                "content": "You will be provided with an input text that consists of Premises and Conclusions. Your task is to determine whether the conclusion is True, False, or Uncertain based solely on the premises. To do this, generate natural language reasoning steps that lead to your final answer.\n\nThe input text is structured as follows:\n- The premises are enclosed within <Premises> and </Premises>.\n- The conclusion is enclosed within <Conclusion> and </Conclusion>.\n- The question is enclosed within <Question> and </Question>.\n- The answer options are provided within <Options> and </Options>.\n\nYour output should include:\n1. A reasoning section enclosed within <Reasoning> and </Reasoning> that explains your thought process.\n2. The final answer enclosed within <Answer> and </Answer>.\n\n\n\nBelow are three examples that demonstrate the desired reasoning style:\n\n<EXAMPLE 1>\n<Premises>\nPeter Parker is either a superhero or a civilian.\nThe Hulk is a destroyer.\nThe Hulk wakes up when he is angry.\nIf the Hulk wakes up, then he will break a bridge.\nThor is a god.\nThor will break a bridge when he is happy.\nA god is not a destroyer.\nPeter Parker wears a uniform when he is a superhero.\nPeter Parker is not a civilian if a destroyer is breaking a bridge.\nIf Thor is happy, the Hulk is angry.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nIf Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform.\n</Question> \n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\nStep 1: given premises \"If Thor is happy, the Hulk is angry.\" and \"The Hulk wakes up when he is angry.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then hulk wakes up.\"\nStep 2: given premise \"If the Hulk wakes up, then he will break a bridge.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then hulk wakes up.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then hulk will break a bridge.\"\nStep 3: given premise \"The Hulk is a destroyer.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then hulk will break a bridge.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then a destroyer will break a bridge.\"\nStep 4: given premise \"Peter Parker is not a civilian if a destroyer is breaking a bridge.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then a destroyer will break a bridge.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is not a civilian\"\nStep 5: given premise \"Peter Parker is either a superhero or a civilian.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is not a civilian\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is a superhero.\"\nStep 6: given premise \"Peter Parker wears a uniform when he is a superhero.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is a superhero.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform\"\nTherefore, the answer is (A).\n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</Answer>\n</EXAMPLE 1>\n\n<EXAMPLE 2>\n<Premises>\nAll philosophers reason.\nSome sophists reason.\nAll who can reason can distinguish truth from falsehood.\nNobody who can distinguish truth from falsehood is morally perfect.\nThe theistic God is morally perfect.\nThe theistic God is a sophist.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nThe theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? The theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</Question>\n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\nStep 1: From the premise \u201cAll philosophers reason,\u201d we know that if someone is a philosopher, then that individual necessarily has the ability to reason.\nStep 2: From the premise \u201cAll who can reason can distinguish truth from falsehood,\u201d we conclude that if someone reasons, they will also distinguish truth from falsehood.\nStep 3: The premise \u201cNobody who can distinguish truth from falsehood is morally perfect\u201d implies that if one does indeed distinguish truth from falsehood, they cannot be morally perfect.\nStep 4: Since the theistic God is stated to be \u201cmorally perfect,\u201d if the theistic God were a philosopher, He would have to reason (by Step 1), which would lead to distinguishing truth from falsehood (by Step 2), thereby making Him not morally perfect (by Step 3). This contradicts the premise that the theistic God is morally perfect, so He cannot be a philosopher.\nStep 5: Separately, the premise says \u201cThe theistic God is a sophist.\u201d We also know \u201cSome sophists reason,\u201d which does not imply that every sophist necessarily reasons. Hence, there is no guaranteed contradiction in being a sophist while remaining morally perfect\u2014He could be the sort of sophist who does not reason.\nStep 6: Because the theistic God cannot be both morally perfect and a philosopher, the statement \u201cThe theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher\u201d is false.\nTherefore, the answer is (B). \n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</Answer>\n</EXAMPLE 2>\n\n<EXAMPLE 3>\n<Premises>\nWilliam Dickinson was a British politician who sat in the House of Commons William Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh. \nThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom. \nWilliam Dickinson supported the Portland Whigs. \nPeople who supported the Portland Whigs did not get a seat in the Parliament.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? William Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</Question> \n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\nStep 1: The premise states that \u201cWilliam Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh.\u201d We also know that \u201cThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom,\u201d so we can confirm that William Dickinson\u2019s university education took place in the UK.\nStep 2: However, the premise does not explicitly state that Westminster School is located in the UK. Although many readers might know from general knowledge that Westminster School is in London, the text itself does not provide this information.\nStep 3: Since the conclusion claims that \u201cWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university,\u201d we can confirm the university part is in the UK but have insufficient information about the high school (Westminster School).\nStep 4: Because the premise does not definitively place Westminster School in the UK, it is impossible to conclude with certainty that both schools he attended were in the UK. We therefore lack enough textual evidence to deem the conclusion strictly true.\nStep 5: There is also no premise suggesting that Westminster School is outside of the UK, so we cannot declare the conclusion false. The conclusion could be true in reality, but the text does not confirm it.\nStep 6: As a result, the statement \u201cWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university\u201d remains unverified by the given premises and is thus uncertain.\nTherefore, the answer is (C). \n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (C).\n</Answer>\n</EXAMPLE 3>\n\n\n\nThe following is the problem you need to solve.\n\n<Premises>\nAnimals are either invertebrates or vertebrates.\nAll animals with backbones reproduce by male-and-female mating. \nAll vertebrate animals have a backbone.\nAll bees do not reproduce by male-and-female mating.\nAll queen bees are bees.\nHarry is a bee.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nHarry is a queen bee.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? Harry is a queen bee.\n</Question>\n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\n"

        "premises": "Animals are either invertebrates or vertebrates.\nAll animals with backbones reproduce by male-and-female mating. \nAll vertebrate animals have a backbone.\nAll bees do not reproduce by male-and-female mating.\nAll queen bees are bees.\nHarry is a bee.",
        "conclusions": "Harry is an invertebrate or a queen bee.",
        "rationale": "Step 1: Given the premise \"Animals are either invertebrates or vertebrates,\" we know that every animal must be classified as either an invertebrate or a vertebrate.\nStep 2: The premise \"All animals with backbones reproduce by male-and-female mating\" and \"All vertebrate animals have a backbone\" imply that all vertebrates reproduce by male-and-female mating. This is because having a backbone is a characteristic of vertebrates.\nStep 3: From the premise \"All bees do not reproduce by male-and-female mating,\" we can infer that bees cannot be vertebrates, as vertebrates reproduce by male-and-female mating.\nStep 4: Given the premise \"All queen bees are bees,\" and the derivation that bees are not vertebrates, we can conclude that queen bees are not vertebrates.\nStep 5: The premise \"Harry is a bee\" allows us to conclude that Harry is not a vertebrate, as we've established that bees are not vertebrates.\nStep 6: From the premise \"Animals are either invertebrates or vertebrates\" and the derivation that Harry is not a vertebrate, we can conclude that Harry must be an invertebrate.\nStep 7: Since Harry is a bee, and bees are not vertebrates, it is certain that Harry is an invertebrate. However, the conclusion also states \"or a queen bee.\" Since the premises do not provide any information about Harry's status as a queen bee, we cannot determine if Harry is a queen bee based on the given information.\nStep 8: Therefore, the conclusion that \"Harry is an invertebrate or a queen bee\" is true, but it is incomplete because it is certain that Harry is an invertebrate but uncertain whether he is a queen bee.\nTherefore, the answer is (A), but with the clarification that the uncertainty lies in the \"or a queen bee\" part.\n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</Answer>",

        "premises": "Animals are either invertebrates or vertebrates.\nAll animals with backbones reproduce by male-and-female mating. \nAll vertebrate animals have a backbone.\nAll bees do not reproduce by male-and-female mating.\nAll queen bees are bees.\nHarry is a bee.",
        "conclusions": "If Harry is either both a vertebrate and an animal with a backbone, or neither a vertebrate nor an animal with a backbone, then Harry is neither an invertebrate nor a queen bee.",
        "rationale": "Step 1: From the premise \"All animals are either invertebrates or vertebrates,\" we know that Harry must be either an invertebrate or a vertebrate.\nStep 2: From the premise \"All vertebrate animals have a backbone,\" we can infer that if Harry is a vertebrate, then Harry has a backbone.\nStep 3: From the premise \"All animals with backbones reproduce by male-and-female mating,\" we can infer that if Harry has a backbone, then Harry reproduces by male-and-female mating.\nStep 4: From the premise \"All bees do not reproduce by male-and-female mating,\" we can infer that if Harry is a bee, then Harry does not reproduce by male-and-female mating.\nStep 5: Since Harry is a bee (premise), we can conclude that Harry does not reproduce by male-and-female mating.\nStep 6: From Step 3 and Step 5, we have a contradiction: if Harry has a backbone, then Harry reproduces by male-and-female mating, but we also know that Harry does not reproduce by male-and-female mating. This means that Harry cannot have a backbone.\nStep 7: Given that Harry is a bee, and all bees do not reproduce by male-and-female mating, we cannot conclude that Harry is an invertebrate, as that would be a possibility based on Step 1.\nStep 8: However, from the premises, we cannot definitively determine if Harry is a vertebrate or not, only that Harry cannot have a backbone (Step 6).\nStep 9: Therefore, the condition \"Harry is either both a vertebrate and an animal with a backbone\" is impossible, as Harry cannot have a backbone.\nStep 10: The condition \"Harry is neither a vertebrate nor an animal with a backbone\" is also possible, as we know Harry cannot have a backbone.\nStep 11: Since the condition for the conclusion is satisfied (the condition is a disjunction of two possibilities, one of which is true), we can conclude that the statement is true.\n\nTherefore, the answer is (A).\n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</Answer>",

        "premises": "People who are born in a multiple birth with siblings spend a lot of time hanging out with and playing with their siblings.\nIf people have siblings who were born together, then they were born in a multiple birth.\nIf people complain often about annoying siblings, then they have siblings who were born together.\nIf people live at home, then they do not live with strangers.\nIf people spend a lot of time hanging out with and playing with their siblings, then they often live at home. \nLuke either is a baby born in a multiple birth and live with strangers, or is not a baby born in a multiple birth and does not live with strangers",
        "conclusions": "Luke spends a lot of time hanging out and playing with his siblings.",
        "rationale": "Step 1: The premise states that \"People who are born in a multiple birth with siblings spend a lot of time hanging out with and playing with their siblings.\" This establishes a relationship between being in a multiple birth and spending time with siblings.\nStep 2: The premise also states that \"If people have siblings who were born together, then they were born in a multiple birth.\" This implies that having siblings born together is a necessary condition for being in a multiple birth.\nStep 3: From Steps 1 and 2, we can infer that if someone has siblings born together, then they spend a lot of time hanging out with and playing with their siblings.\nStep 4: The premise \"If people complain often about annoying siblings, then they have siblings who were born together\" does not directly impact our conclusion, but it does imply that having siblings born together is a sufficient condition for complaining about annoying siblings.\nStep 5: The premise \"If people live at home, then they do not live with strangers\" and \"If people spend a lot of time hanging out with and playing with their siblings, then they often live at home\" establish a relationship between living at home, not living with strangers, and spending time with siblings.\nStep 6: However, the premise \"Luke either is a baby born in a multiple birth and live with strangers, or is not a baby born in a multiple birth and does not live with strangers\" provides an exclusive disjunction, implying that Luke cannot both live with strangers and not live with strangers. This means that if Luke lives with strangers, then he is not born in a multiple birth, and if he does not live with strangers, then he is born in a multiple birth.\nStep 7: Since we established in Step 3 that people born in a multiple birth spend a lot of time hanging out with and playing with their siblings, and in Step 6 that Luke either lives with strangers or is born in a multiple birth, we can infer that if Luke is not born in a multiple birth, then he does not spend a lot of time hanging out and playing with his siblings (because the conditions for this are mutually exclusive with the conditions for living with strangers).\nStep 8: However, the premises do not provide direct information about Luke's living situation or the number of his siblings, making it impossible to definitively determine whether he is born in a multiple birth or not.\nStep 9: As a result, the statement \"Luke spends a lot of time hanging out and playing with his siblings\" remains uncertain because we cannot conclusively determine the truth of the underlying conditions.\nTherefore, the answer is (C). \n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (C).\n</Answer>",
        "label": "Uncertain",
        "predict": "Uncertain",
        "user_prompt": [
            {
                "role": "user",
                "content": "You will be provided with an input text that consists of Premises and Conclusions. Your task is to determine whether the conclusion is True, False, or Uncertain based solely on the premises. To do this, generate natural language reasoning steps that lead to your final answer.\n\nThe input text is structured as follows:\n- The premises are enclosed within <Premises> and </Premises>.\n- The conclusion is enclosed within <Conclusion> and </Conclusion>.\n- The question is enclosed within <Question> and </Question>.\n- The answer options are provided within <Options> and </Options>.\n\nYour output should include:\n1. A reasoning section enclosed within <Reasoning> and </Reasoning> that explains your thought process.\n2. The final answer enclosed within <Answer> and </Answer>.\n\n\n\nBelow are three examples that demonstrate the desired reasoning style:\n\n<EXAMPLE 1>\n<Premises>\nPeter Parker is either a superhero or a civilian.\nThe Hulk is a destroyer.\nThe Hulk wakes up when he is angry.\nIf the Hulk wakes up, then he will break a bridge.\nThor is a god.\nThor will break a bridge when he is happy.\nA god is not a destroyer.\nPeter Parker wears a uniform when he is a superhero.\nPeter Parker is not a civilian if a destroyer is breaking a bridge.\nIf Thor is happy, the Hulk is angry.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nIf Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform.\n</Question> \n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\nStep 1: given premises \"If Thor is happy, the Hulk is angry.\" and \"The Hulk wakes up when he is angry.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then hulk wakes up.\"\nStep 2: given premise \"If the Hulk wakes up, then he will break a bridge.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then hulk wakes up.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then hulk will break a bridge.\"\nStep 3: given premise \"The Hulk is a destroyer.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then hulk will break a bridge.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then a destroyer will break a bridge.\"\nStep 4: given premise \"Peter Parker is not a civilian if a destroyer is breaking a bridge.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then a destroyer will break a bridge.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is not a civilian\"\nStep 5: given premise \"Peter Parker is either a superhero or a civilian.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is not a civilian\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is a superhero.\"\nStep 6: given premise \"Peter Parker wears a uniform when he is a superhero.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is a superhero.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform\"\nTherefore, the answer is (A).\n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</Answer>\n</EXAMPLE 1>\n\n<EXAMPLE 2>\n<Premises>\nAll philosophers reason.\nSome sophists reason.\nAll who can reason can distinguish truth from falsehood.\nNobody who can distinguish truth from falsehood is morally perfect.\nThe theistic God is morally perfect.\nThe theistic God is a sophist.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nThe theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? The theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</Question>\n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\nStep 1: From the premise \u201cAll philosophers reason,\u201d we know that if someone is a philosopher, then that individual necessarily has the ability to reason.\nStep 2: From the premise \u201cAll who can reason can distinguish truth from falsehood,\u201d we conclude that if someone reasons, they will also distinguish truth from falsehood.\nStep 3: The premise \u201cNobody who can distinguish truth from falsehood is morally perfect\u201d implies that if one does indeed distinguish truth from falsehood, they cannot be morally perfect.\nStep 4: Since the theistic God is stated to be \u201cmorally perfect,\u201d if the theistic God were a philosopher, He would have to reason (by Step 1), which would lead to distinguishing truth from falsehood (by Step 2), thereby making Him not morally perfect (by Step 3). This contradicts the premise that the theistic God is morally perfect, so He cannot be a philosopher.\nStep 5: Separately, the premise says \u201cThe theistic God is a sophist.\u201d We also know \u201cSome sophists reason,\u201d which does not imply that every sophist necessarily reasons. Hence, there is no guaranteed contradiction in being a sophist while remaining morally perfect\u2014He could be the sort of sophist who does not reason.\nStep 6: Because the theistic God cannot be both morally perfect and a philosopher, the statement \u201cThe theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher\u201d is false.\nTherefore, the answer is (B). \n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</Answer>\n</EXAMPLE 2>\n\n<EXAMPLE 3>\n<Premises>\nWilliam Dickinson was a British politician who sat in the House of Commons William Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh. \nThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom. \nWilliam Dickinson supported the Portland Whigs. \nPeople who supported the Portland Whigs did not get a seat in the Parliament.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? William Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</Question> \n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\nStep 1: The premise states that \u201cWilliam Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh.\u201d We also know that \u201cThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom,\u201d so we can confirm that William Dickinson\u2019s university education took place in the UK.\nStep 2: However, the premise does not explicitly state that Westminster School is located in the UK. Although many readers might know from general knowledge that Westminster School is in London, the text itself does not provide this information.\nStep 3: Since the conclusion claims that \u201cWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university,\u201d we can confirm the university part is in the UK but have insufficient information about the high school (Westminster School).\nStep 4: Because the premise does not definitively place Westminster School in the UK, it is impossible to conclude with certainty that both schools he attended were in the UK. We therefore lack enough textual evidence to deem the conclusion strictly true.\nStep 5: There is also no premise suggesting that Westminster School is outside of the UK, so we cannot declare the conclusion false. The conclusion could be true in reality, but the text does not confirm it.\nStep 6: As a result, the statement \u201cWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university\u201d remains unverified by the given premises and is thus uncertain.\nTherefore, the answer is (C). \n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (C).\n</Answer>\n</EXAMPLE 3>\n\n\n\nThe following is the problem you need to solve.\n\n<Premises>\nPeople who are born in a multiple birth with siblings spend a lot of time hanging out with and playing with their siblings.\nIf people have siblings who were born together, then they were born in a multiple birth.\nIf people complain often about annoying siblings, then they have siblings who were born together.\nIf people live at home, then they do not live with strangers.\nIf people spend a lot of time hanging out with and playing with their siblings, then they often live at home. \nLuke either is a baby born in a multiple birth and live with strangers, or is not a baby born in a multiple birth and does not live with strangers\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nLuke spends a lot of time hanging out and playing with his siblings.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? Luke spends a lot of time hanging out and playing with his siblings.\n</Question>\n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\n"
            }

        "conclusions": "Luke complains often about annoying siblings.",
        "rationale": "Step 1: Given the premise \"If people have siblings who were born together, then they were born in a multiple birth,\" we can infer that having siblings who were born together is a condition for being born in a multiple birth.\nStep 2: From the premise \"People who are born in a multiple birth with siblings spend a lot of time hanging out with and playing with their siblings,\" we can deduce that spending a lot of time with siblings is a characteristic of those born in a multiple birth.\nStep 3: Combining the inferences from Steps 1 and 2, we can conclude that spending a lot of time with siblings implies having siblings who were born together, which in turn implies being born in a multiple birth.\nStep 4: Given the premise \"If people spend a lot of time hanging out with and playing with their siblings, then they often live at home,\" we can deduce that spending a lot of time with siblings is a condition for living at home.\nStep 5: From the premise \"If people live at home, then they do not live with strangers,\" we can infer that living at home is a condition for not living with strangers.\nStep 6: Given the premise \"Luke either is a baby born in a multiple birth and live with strangers, or is not a baby born in a multiple birth and does not live with strangers,\" we can analyze the two options:\n    - If Luke is a baby born in a multiple birth and lives with strangers, then he must not spend a lot of time with siblings (by Steps 3 and 4), which contradicts the premise \"People who are born in a multiple birth with siblings spend a lot of time hanging out with and playing with their siblings.\"\n    - If Luke is not a baby born in a multiple birth and does not live with strangers, then he must spend a lot of time with siblings (by Steps 3 and 5), which implies he has siblings who were born together (by Step 2), and thus he complains often about annoying siblings (by the premise \"If people complain often about annoying siblings, then they have siblings who were born together\").\nStep 7: Based on the analysis in Step 6, we can see that Luke complaining often about annoying siblings is a possible conclusion if he is not a baby born in a multiple birth and does not live with strangers. However, the premise \"Luke either is a baby born in a multiple birth and live with strangers, or is not a baby born in a multiple birth and does not live with strangers\" does not provide a definitive answer about whether Luke complains about his siblings or not, as it leaves both possibilities open.\nStep 8: Since the conclusion can be true if one of the possibilities is true (Luke is not a baby born in a multiple birth and does not live with strangers), but cannot be definitively proven or disproven by the premises, the conclusion is uncertain.\nTherefore, the answer is (C).\n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (C).\n</Answer>",

        "premises": "People who are born in a multiple birth with siblings spend a lot of time hanging out with and playing with their siblings.\nIf people have siblings who were born together, then they were born in a multiple birth.\nIf people complain often about annoying siblings, then they have siblings who were born together.\nIf people live at home, then they do not live with strangers.\nIf people spend a lot of time hanging out with and playing with their siblings, then they often live at home. \nLuke either is a baby born in a multiple birth and live with strangers, or is not a baby born in a multiple birth and does not live with strangers",
        "conclusions": "Luke is neither born in a multiple birth nor complains often about annoying siblings.",
        "rationale": "Step 1: Given the premise \"People who are born in a multiple birth with siblings spend a lot of time hanging out with and playing with their siblings,\" we can deduce that if someone is born in a multiple birth, then they spend a lot of time with their siblings.\nStep 2: From the premise \"If people have siblings who were born together, then they were born in a multiple birth,\" we can conclude that if someone has siblings who were born together, they must have been born in a multiple birth.\nStep 3: From the premise \"If people complain often about annoying siblings, then they have siblings who were born together,\" we can infer that if someone complains often about annoying siblings, then they must have siblings who were born together.\nStep 4: Given the premise \"If people spend a lot of time hanging out with and playing with their siblings, then they often live at home,\" we can deduce that if someone spends a lot of time with their siblings, they often live at home.\nStep 5: The premise \"Luke either is a baby born in a multiple birth and live with strangers, or is not a baby born in a multiple birth and does not live with strangers\" provides us with a disjunction, which we will use to analyze the possibilities.\nStep 6: If Luke is a baby born in a multiple birth and lives with strangers, then he must spend a lot of time with his siblings (by Step 1). However, if he lives with strangers, then he cannot live at home (by the premise \"If people live at home, then they do not live with strangers\"). This implies that he spends a lot of time with his siblings but does not live at home, which contradicts the premise \"If people spend a lot of time hanging out with and playing with their siblings, then they often live at home.\"\nStep 7: This contradiction means that Luke cannot be a baby born in a multiple birth and live with strangers. Therefore, he must be not a baby born in a multiple birth and does not live with strangers (by the disjunction premise).\nStep 8: If Luke is not a baby born in a multiple birth, then he cannot have siblings who were born together (by Step 2). Therefore, he does not have siblings who were born together.\nStep 9: Since Luke does not have siblings who were born together, he cannot complain often about annoying siblings (by Step 3).\nStep 10: Therefore, we can conclude that Luke is neither born in a multiple birth nor complains often about annoying siblings.\nTherefore, the answer is (A).\n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</Answer>",

This contradicts the premise that the theistic God is morally perfect, so He cannot be a philosopher.\nStep 5: Separately, the premise says \u201cThe theistic God is a sophist.\u201d We also know \u201cSome sophists reason,\u201d which does not imply that every sophist necessarily reasons. Hence, there is no guaranteed contradiction in being a sophist while remaining morally perfect\u2014He could be the sort of sophist who does not reason.\nStep 6: Because the theistic God cannot be both morally perfect and a philosopher, the statement \u201cThe theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher\u201d is false.\nTherefore, the answer is (B). \n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</Answer>\n</EXAMPLE 2>\n\n<EXAMPLE 3>\n<Premises>\nWilliam Dickinson was a British politician who sat in the House of Commons William Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh. \nThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom. \nWilliam Dickinson supported the Portland Whigs. \nPeople who supported the Portland Whigs did not get a seat in the Parliament.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? William Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</Question> \n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\nStep 1: The premise states that \u201cWilliam Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh.\u201d We also know that \u201cThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom,\u201d so we can confirm that William Dickinson\u2019s university education took place in the UK.\nStep 2: However, the premise does not explicitly state that Westminster School is located in the UK. Although many readers might know from general knowledge that Westminster School is in London, the text itself does not provide this information.\nStep 3: Since the conclusion claims that \u201cWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university,\u201d we can confirm the university part is in the UK but have insufficient information about the high school (Westminster School).\nStep 4: Because the premise does not definitively place Westminster School in the UK, it is impossible to conclude with certainty that both schools he attended were in the UK. We therefore lack enough textual evidence to deem the conclusion strictly true.\nStep 5: There is also no premise suggesting that Westminster School is outside of the UK, so we cannot declare the conclusion false. The conclusion could be true in reality, but the text does not confirm it.\nStep 6: As a result, the statement \u201cWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university\u201d remains unverified by the given premises and is thus uncertain.\nTherefore, the answer is (C). \n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (C).\n</Answer>\n</EXAMPLE 3>\n\n\n\nThe following is the problem you need to solve.\n\n<Premises>\nPeople who are born in a multiple birth with siblings spend a lot of time hanging out with and playing with their siblings.\nIf people have siblings who were born together, then they were born in a multiple birth.\nIf people complain often about annoying siblings, then they have siblings who were born together.\nIf people live at home, then they do not live with strangers.\nIf people spend a lot of time hanging out with and playing with their siblings, then they often live at home. \nLuke either is a baby born in a multiple birth and live with strangers, or is not a baby born in a multiple birth and does not live with strangers\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nLuke is neither born in a multiple birth nor complains often about annoying siblings.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? Luke is neither born in a multiple birth nor complains often about annoying siblings.\n</Question>\n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\n"

Therefore, Tom can prove economic hardship.\nStep 4: Since Tom can prove economic hardship, we can conclude that ETS provides financial aid to Tom, as he meets the condition for receiving financial aid.\nStep 5: Given the information that it is cheaper for Tom to take the test and that ETS provides financial aid to those who prove economic hardship, which Tom can do, it follows that Tom is eligible for financial aid.\nStep 6: Therefore, the statement \"ETS provides financial aid to Tom\" can be concluded as true based on the given premises.\nTherefore, the answer is (A).\n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</Answer>",

                "role": "user",
                "content": "You will be provided with an input text that consists of Premises and Conclusions. Your task is to determine whether the conclusion is True, False, or Uncertain based solely on the premises. To do this, generate natural language reasoning steps that lead to your final answer.\n\nThe input text is structured as follows:\n- The premises are enclosed within <Premises> and </Premises>.\n- The conclusion is enclosed within <Conclusion> and </Conclusion>.\n- The question is enclosed within <Question> and </Question>.\n- The answer options are provided within <Options> and </Options>.\n\nYour output should include:\n1. A reasoning section enclosed within <Reasoning> and </Reasoning> that explains your thought process.\n2. The final answer enclosed within <Answer> and </Answer>.\n\n\n\nBelow are three examples that demonstrate the desired reasoning style:\n\n<EXAMPLE 1>\n<Premises>\nPeter Parker is either a superhero or a civilian.\nThe Hulk is a destroyer.\nThe Hulk wakes up when he is angry.\nIf the Hulk wakes up, then he will break a bridge.\nThor is a god.\nThor will break a bridge when he is happy.\nA god is not a destroyer.\nPeter Parker wears a uniform when he is a superhero.\nPeter Parker is not a civilian if a destroyer is breaking a bridge.\nIf Thor is happy, the Hulk is angry.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nIf Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform.\n</Question> \n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\nStep 1: given premises \"If Thor is happy, the Hulk is angry.\" and \"The Hulk wakes up when he is angry.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then hulk wakes up.\"\nStep 2: given premise \"If the Hulk wakes up, then he will break a bridge.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then hulk wakes up.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then hulk will break a bridge.\"\nStep 3: given premise \"The Hulk is a destroyer.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then hulk will break a bridge.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then a destroyer will break a bridge.\"\nStep 4: given premise \"Peter Parker is not a civilian if a destroyer is breaking a bridge.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then a destroyer will break a bridge.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is not a civilian\"\nStep 5: given premise \"Peter Parker is either a superhero or a civilian.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is not a civilian\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is a superhero.\"\nStep 6: given premise \"Peter Parker wears a uniform when he is a superhero.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is a superhero.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform\"\nTherefore, the answer is (A).\n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</Answer>\n</EXAMPLE 1>\n\n<EXAMPLE 2>\n<Premises>\nAll philosophers reason.\nSome sophists reason.\nAll who can reason can distinguish truth from falsehood.\nNobody who can distinguish truth from falsehood is morally perfect.\nThe theistic God is morally perfect.\nThe theistic God is a sophist.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nThe theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? The theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</Question>\n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\nStep 1: From the premise \u201cAll philosophers reason,\u201d we know that if someone is a philosopher, then that individual necessarily has the ability to reason.\nStep 2: From the premise \u201cAll who can reason can distinguish truth from falsehood,\u201d we conclude that if someone reasons, they will also distinguish truth from falsehood.\nStep 3: The premise \u201cNobody who can distinguish truth from falsehood is morally perfect\u201d implies that if one does indeed distinguish truth from falsehood, they cannot be morally perfect.\nStep 4: Since the theistic God is stated to be \u201cmorally perfect,\u201d if the theistic God were a philosopher, He would have to reason (by Step 1), which would lead to distinguishing truth from falsehood (by Step 2), thereby making Him not morally perfect (by Step 3). This contradicts the premise that the theistic God is morally perfect, so He cannot be a philosopher.\nStep 5: Separately, the premise says \u201cThe theistic God is a sophist.\u201d We also know \u201cSome sophists reason,\u201d which does not imply that every sophist necessarily reasons. Hence, there is no guaranteed contradiction in being a sophist while remaining morally perfect\u2014He could be the sort of sophist who does not reason.\nStep 6: Because the theistic God cannot be both morally perfect and a philosopher, the statement \u201cThe theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher\u201d is false.\nTherefore, the answer is (B). \n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</Answer>\n</EXAMPLE 2>\n\n<EXAMPLE 3>\n<Premises>\nWilliam Dickinson was a British politician who sat in the House of Commons William Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh. \nThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom. \nWilliam Dickinson supported the Portland Whigs. \nPeople who supported the Portland Whigs did not get a seat in the Parliament.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? Hence, there is no guaranteed contradiction in being a sophist while remaining morally perfect\u2014He could be the sort of sophist who does not reason.\nStep 6: Because the theistic God cannot be both morally perfect and a philosopher, the statement \u201cThe theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher\u201d is false.\nTherefore, the answer is (B). \n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</Answer>\n</EXAMPLE 2>\n\n<EXAMPLE 3>\n<Premises>\nWilliam Dickinson was a British politician who sat in the House of Commons William Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh. \nThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom. \nWilliam Dickinson supported the Portland Whigs. \nPeople who supported the Portland Whigs did not get a seat in the Parliament.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? Although many readers might know from general knowledge that Westminster School is in London, the text itself does not provide this information.\nStep 3: Since the conclusion claims that \u201cWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university,\u201d we can confirm the university part is in the UK but have insufficient information about the high school (Westminster School).\nStep 4: Because the premise does not definitively place Westminster School in the UK, it is impossible to conclude with certainty that both schools he attended were in the UK. We therefore lack enough textual evidence to deem the conclusion strictly true.\nStep 5: There is also no premise suggesting that Westminster School is outside of the UK, so we cannot declare the conclusion false. The conclusion could be true in reality, but the text does not confirm it.\nStep 6: As a result, the statement \u201cWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university\u201d remains unverified by the given premises and is thus uncertain.\nTherefore, the answer is (C). \n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (C).\n</Answer>\n</EXAMPLE 3>\n\n\n\nThe following is the problem you need to solve.\n\n<Premises>\nIt costs $205 to take the GRE test, which is cheaper than $300.\nETS provides financial aid to those GRE applicants who prove economic hardship.\nThose living in single-parent families or having few resources available to them can prove economic hardship.\nTom lives in a single-parent family.\nTom's dad has been out of work, and Tom has few resources available to them. \nTom is applying to take the GRE test.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nNo one taking the GRE test has financial aid provided to them by something.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? No one taking the GRE test has financial aid provided to them by something.\n</Question>\n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\n"

        "premises": "If people spill a lot of food on their clothing, then they are not notably tidy.\nAll clumsy foodies who go out frequently to find new food restaurants to try are people who spill a lot of food on their clothing.\nIf people are cleanly, then they are notably tidy.\nIf people value order and spotlessness, then they are cleanly.\nAll people whose families prioritize order and spotlessness themselves value order and spotlessness.\nPeter is either a person who spills a lot of food on his clothing and is cleanly, or a person who does not spill a lot of food on his clothing and is not cleanly",
        "conclusions": "Peter is notably tidy.",
        "rationale": "Step 1: From the premise \u201cIf people spill a lot of food on their clothing, then they are not notably tidy,\u201d we know that if someone is notably tidy, they cannot be someone who spills a lot of food on their clothing.\nStep 2: The premise \u201cAll clumsy foodies who go out frequently to find new food restaurants to try are people who spill a lot of food on their clothing\u201d tells us that if someone is a clumsy foodie who goes out frequently, they spill a lot of food on their clothing. However, this does not directly tell us about Peter's tidiness.\nStep 3: The premise \u201cPeter is either a person who spills a lot of food on his clothing and is cleanly, or a person who does not spill a lot of food on his clothing and is not cleanly\u201d provides two possible scenarios for Peter's behavior.\nStep 4: Given that Peter could be someone who spills a lot of food on his clothing and is cleanly, we can use the first premise to infer that if he spills a lot of food on his clothing, he is not notably tidy (Step 1). However, being cleanly would make him notably tidy (Step 5).\nStep 5: However, if Peter is cleanly, then he is notably tidy, as stated in the premise \u201cIf people are cleanly, then they are notably tidy\u201d (Step 1).\nStep 6: From the premise \u201cAll people whose families prioritize order and spotlessness themselves value order and spotlessness,\u201d we can conclude that if Peter's family values order and spotlessness, then Peter values order and spotlessness (Step 7).\nStep 7: The premise \u201cIf people value order and spotlessness, then they are cleanly\u201d implies that if Peter values order and spotlessness, he is cleanly (Step 6).\nStep 8: Since we have established that if Peter is cleanly, he is notably tidy (Step 5), we can conclude that if Peter values order and spotlessness, he is notably tidy (Step 7 and Step 5).\nStep 9: From the premise \u201cPeter is either a person who spills a lot of food on his clothing and is cleanly, or a person who does not spill a lot of food on his clothing and is not cleanly\u201d (Step 3), we can see that if Peter is the first option (spills a lot of food on his clothing and is cleanly), he is notably tidy from Step 4 and Step 5.\nStep 10: If Peter is the second option (does not spill a lot of food on his clothing and is not cleanly), we can use the premise \u201cIf people are cleanly, then they are notably tidy\u201d to conclude that he is not notably tidy, as he is not cleanly.\nStep 11: Therefore, Peter's tidiness status is uncertain, as it depends on which of the two scenarios he fits into.\nTherefore, the answer is (C).\n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (C).\n</Answer>",

Your task is to determine whether the conclusion is True, False, or Uncertain based solely on the premises. To do this, generate natural language reasoning steps that lead to your final answer.\n\nThe input text is structured as follows:\n- The premises are enclosed within <Premises> and </Premises>.\n- The conclusion is enclosed within <Conclusion> and </Conclusion>.\n- The question is enclosed within <Question> and </Question>.\n- The answer options are provided within <Options> and </Options>.\n\nYour output should include:\n1. A reasoning section enclosed within <Reasoning> and </Reasoning> that explains your thought process.\n2. The final answer enclosed within <Answer> and </Answer>.\n\n\n\nBelow are three examples that demonstrate the desired reasoning style:\n\n<EXAMPLE 1>\n<Premises>\nPeter Parker is either a superhero or a civilian.\nThe Hulk is a destroyer.\nThe Hulk wakes up when he is angry.\nIf the Hulk wakes up, then he will break a bridge.\nThor is a god.\nThor will break a bridge when he is happy.\nA god is not a destroyer.\nPeter Parker wears a uniform when he is a superhero.\nPeter Parker is not a civilian if a destroyer is breaking a bridge.\nIf Thor is happy, the Hulk is angry.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nIf Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform.\n</Question> \n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\nStep 1: given premises \"If Thor is happy, the Hulk is angry.\" and \"The Hulk wakes up when he is angry.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then hulk wakes up.\"\nStep 2: given premise \"If the Hulk wakes up, then he will break a bridge.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then hulk wakes up.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then hulk will break a bridge.\"\nStep 3: given premise \"The Hulk is a destroyer.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then hulk will break a bridge.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then a destroyer will break a bridge.\"\nStep 4: given premise \"Peter Parker is not a civilian if a destroyer is breaking a bridge.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then a destroyer will break a bridge.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is not a civilian\"\nStep 5: given premise \"Peter Parker is either a superhero or a civilian.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is not a civilian\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is a superhero.\"\nStep 6: given premise \"Peter Parker wears a uniform when he is a superhero.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is a superhero.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform\"\nTherefore, the answer is (A).\n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</Answer>\n</EXAMPLE 1>\n\n<EXAMPLE 2>\n<Premises>\nAll philosophers reason.\nSome sophists reason.\nAll who can reason can distinguish truth from falsehood.\nNobody who can distinguish truth from falsehood is morally perfect.\nThe theistic God is morally perfect.\nThe theistic God is a sophist.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nThe theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? The theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</Question>\n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\nStep 1: From the premise \u201cAll philosophers reason,\u201d we know that if someone is a philosopher, then that individual necessarily has the ability to reason.\nStep 2: From the premise \u201cAll who can reason can distinguish truth from falsehood,\u201d we conclude that if someone reasons, they will also distinguish truth from falsehood.\nStep 3: The premise \u201cNobody who can distinguish truth from falsehood is morally perfect\u201d implies that if one does indeed distinguish truth from falsehood, they cannot be morally perfect.\nStep 4: Since the theistic God is stated to be \u201cmorally perfect,\u201d if the theistic God were a philosopher, He would have to reason (by Step 1), which would lead to distinguishing truth from falsehood (by Step 2), thereby making Him not morally perfect (by Step 3). This contradicts the premise that the theistic God is morally perfect, so He cannot be a philosopher.\nStep 5: Separately, the premise says \u201cThe theistic God is a sophist.\u201d We also know \u201cSome sophists reason,\u201d which does not imply that every sophist necessarily reasons. Hence, there is no guaranteed contradiction in being a sophist while remaining morally perfect\u2014He could be the sort of sophist who does not reason.\nStep 6: Because the theistic God cannot be both morally perfect and a philosopher, the statement \u201cThe theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher\u201d is false.\nTherefore, the answer is (B). \n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</Answer>\n</EXAMPLE 2>\n\n<EXAMPLE 3>\n<Premises>\nWilliam Dickinson was a British politician who sat in the House of Commons William Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh. \nThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom. \nWilliam Dickinson supported the Portland Whigs. \nPeople who supported the Portland Whigs did not get a seat in the Parliament.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain?         "conclusions": "Peter is either a  clumsy foodie who goes out frequently to find new food restaurants to try or he is someone whose family prioritizes order and spotlessness.",
        "rationale": "Step 1: We start with the premise that Peter is either a person who spills a lot of food on his clothing and is cleanly, or a person who does not spill a lot of food on his clothing and is not cleanly.\nStep 2: Let's analyze the first part of the premise: \"a person who spills a lot of food on his clothing and is cleanly.\" We know that \"If people spill a lot of food on their clothing, then they are not notably tidy.\" and \"If people are cleanly, then they are notably tidy.\" These two premises together imply that being both cleanly and spilling a lot of food on clothing is a contradiction.\nStep 3: Given this contradiction, the first part of the premise is false: \"a person who spills a lot of food on his clothing and is cleanly\" cannot be true.\nStep 4: Therefore, Peter must be \"a person who does not spill a lot of food on his clothing and is not cleanly.\"\nStep 5: We now look at the second part of the original premise: \"a person who does not spill a lot of food on his clothing and is not cleanly.\" If someone is not cleanly, then they are not notably tidy (from the premise \"If people are cleanly, then they are notably tidy\"). We also know that \"If people spill a lot of food on their clothing, then they are not notably tidy.\" Since we've established that Peter does not spill a lot of food on his clothing, this means Peter is notably tidy.\nStep 6: If Peter is notably tidy, then he must value order and spotlessness (from the premise \"If people are cleanly, then they are notably tidy\" and the premise \"If people value order and spotlessness, then they are cleanly\"). Since Peter values order and spotlessness, his family must also prioritize order and spotlessness (from the premise \"All people whose families prioritize order and spotlessness themselves value order and spotlessness\").\nStep 7: Now that we know Peter's family prioritizes order and spotlessness, we can conclude that Peter is indeed \"someone whose family prioritizes order and spotlessness.\"\nStep 8: Since we've identified one of the two options as true for Peter, the statement that \"Peter is either a  clumsy foodie who goes out frequently to find new food restaurants to try or he is someone whose family prioritizes order and spotlessness\" is true.\nTherefore, the answer is (A).\n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</Answer>",

    {
        "premises": "If people spill a lot of food on their clothing, then they are not notably tidy.\nAll clumsy foodies who go out frequently to find new food restaurants to try are people who spill a lot of food on their clothing.\nIf people are cleanly, then they are notably tidy.\nIf people value order and spotlessness, then they are cleanly.\nAll people whose families prioritize order and spotlessness themselves value order and spotlessness.\nPeter is either a person who spills a lot of food on his clothing and is cleanly, or a person who does not spill a lot of food on his clothing and is not cleanly",
        "conclusions": "Peter is either both a clumsy foodie who goes out frequently to find new food restaurants to try and issomeone whose family prioritizes order and spotlessness, or he neither is a clumsy foodie who goes out frequently to find new food restaurants to try nor does his family prioritize order and spotlessness.",
        "rationale": "Step 1: From the premise \"Peter is either a person who spills a lot of food on his clothing and is cleanly, or a person who does not spill a lot of food on his clothing and is not cleanly,\" we know that Peter has two possible scenarios: either he spills food and is cleanly, or he does not spill food and is not cleanly.\nStep 2: Given \"If people are cleanly, then they are notably tidy,\" and \"If people spill a lot of food on their clothing, then they are not notably tidy,\" we can infer that if Peter spills food and is cleanly, then he is tidy.\nStep 3: From \"All clumsy foodies who go out frequently to find new food restaurants to try are people who spill a lot of food on their clothing,\" and the previous step's conclusion that if Peter spills food and is cleanly, then he is tidy, we cannot determine that Peter is a clumsy foodie, as tidiness is not exclusive to clumsy foodies.\nStep 4: From \"All people whose families prioritize order and spotlessness themselves value order and spotlessness,\" we know that if Peter's family prioritizes order and spotlessness, then Peter values order and spotlessness.\nStep 5: Given \"If people value order and spotlessness, then they are cleanly,\" and the previous step's conclusion that if Peter's family prioritizes order and spotlessness, then Peter values order and spotlessness, we can conclude that if Peter's family prioritizes order and spotlessness, then Peter is cleanly.\nStep 6: From \"All clumsy foodies who go out frequently to find new food restaurants to try are people who spill a lot of food on their clothing,\" we know that if Peter is a clumsy foodie, then he spills food.\nStep 7: From steps 2 and 5, we know that if Peter is cleanly, then he is tidy and if his family prioritizes order and spotlessness, then he is cleanly.\nStep 8: From step 1, we know that Peter is either a person who spills a lot of food on his clothing and is cleanly, or a person who does not spill a lot of food on his clothing and is not cleanly.\nStep 9: From steps 6 and 7, we know that if Peter is a clumsy foodie, then he is not cleanly, which contradicts the first part of the disjunction in step 8.\nStep 10: Since the two scenarios in step 8 are mutually exclusive (Peter can't be both a clumsy foodie and cleanly), and one of them (being a clumsy foodie) is impossible, we can conclude that the only possible scenario for Peter is that he does not spill a lot of food on his clothing and is not cleanly.\nStep 11: From step 8, we know that this scenario is the second part of the disjunction \"or he neither is a clumsy foodie who goes out frequently to find new food restaurants to try nor does his family prioritize order and spotlessness.\"\nStep 12: Therefore, the statement \"Peter is either both a clumsy foodie who goes out frequently to find new food restaurants to try and issomeone whose family prioritizes order and spotlessness, or he neither is a clumsy foodie who goes out frequently to find new food restaurants to try nor does his family prioritize order and spotlessness\" is true.\nTherefore, the answer is (A).\n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</Answer>",
